is a Climate and Public Good focused Hackathon leveraging Web3 technologies and principles.

pages.contentText: Welcome your participants! Customize this page for your event. Add your own images by typing /image. Add a new callout by typing /callout. You may delete any block by clicking the  ⋮⋮ to the left on hover.Welcome to Good HackFeb 9-17, 2023Feb 9-17 ONLINE | Feb 9-12 IRL @ at Verci (17 John St, New York, NY)TL;DRGOOD HACK NYC is a Climate and Public Good focused Hackathon leveraging Web3 technologies and principles.GOOD HACK is non-technical and attendees are not expected to write code. However, general technical specs will be required for the final submission.Teams receive mentorship from climate/climate tech experts throughout the hackathon.Click LOG IN [<- add invite link here] to join the space.Help your participants easily navigate your space. Add links to new pages below by typing /link to page. SHOUT OUTSSpecial thank you to our partners and mentors: CharmVerse, Collab.Land, Lit Protocol, and CyberConnect.

children.title: Event Details

content.text: Feb 9-12 IRL @ at Verci (17 John St, New York, NY)

On February 12, hackers can submit completed projects, design studies, and proofs-of-concept for public consideration. The best projects will be offered further grants, mentoring, investments, and/or partnerships.
**Final projects must be submitted by Sunday, February 12th at 12pm EST
Sponsored by GreenNFT in partnership with BSIC
Hacker’s eligible for this track, must submit a coherent and actionable project concept demonstrating a capacity to make a material impact on the climate climate crisis.
Innovation around carbon credits pricing, trade, and verification.
Financial mechanisms for funding climate projects
Climate impact and project information access
Innovative approach deploying Blockchain tech (extra consideration for project that utilize NFT or related technologies)
Potential for material impact on the climate crises
Decentralized "money legos" have a massive potential in driving real-world impact. Build a project that contributes to a positive sum future for all.
Crowdfunding dApp (web3 version of GoFundMe, Kickstarter, Patreon, etc.)
Funding mechanisms: NFT auction, Nouns fork, quadratic funding, etc.
Innovative approaches to leveraging web3 tooling for public goods
- $7,000 (Sponsored by GreenNFT in partnership with BSIC)

children.contentText: Feb 9-17 ONLINE | Feb 9-12 IRL @ at Verci (17 John St, New York, NY)SUBMISSIONSOn February 12, hackers can submit completed projects, design studies, and proofs-of-concept for public consideration. The best projects will be offered further grants, mentoring, investments, and/or partnerships.**Final projects must be submitted by Sunday, February 12th at 12pm EST TRACKSClimate - Sponsored by GreenNFT in partnership with BSICHacker’s eligible for this track, must submit a coherent and actionable project concept demonstrating a capacity to make a material impact on the climate climate crisis.Ideas to explore: Innovation around carbon credits pricing, trade, and verification.Financial mechanisms for funding climate projectsClimate impact and project information access  Judging criteria:Innovative approach deploying Blockchain tech (extra consideration for project that utilize NFT or related technologies)Potential for material impact on the climate crisesTechnical feasibility Economic & business viability Public Goods - Sponsored by MantleDecentralized "money legos" have a massive potential in driving real-world impact. Build a project that contributes to a positive sum future for all. Ideas to explore:Crowdfunding dApp (web3 version of GoFundMe, Kickstarter, Patreon, etc.)Gamification: leaderboard, reputation score, etc.Funding mechanisms: NFT auction, Nouns fork, quadratic funding, etc.Judging criteria:Innovative approaches to leveraging web3 tooling for public goodsRelevance and impactPotential for adoptionTechnical feasibilityBonus: can be built on MantlePRIZESClimate bounties - $7,000 (Sponsored by GreenNFT in partnership with BSIC)1st prize $25002nd prize $15003rd prize $1000Online: 2 x $1000Public Goods bounties - $8,000 (Sponsored by Mantle)1st prize $30002nd prize $20003rd prize $1000Online: 2x $2000

children.title: IRL Schedule

content.text: , 17 John Street, New York, NY (lower Manhattan)
Joel (Last of Us), Fleabag (Fleabag), Mike (Stranger Things), Charlie (Poker Face)
, hackers can submit completed projects, design studies, and proofs-of-concept for public consideration.
The best projects will be offered further grants, mentoring, investments, and/or partnerships.

children.contentText: WHEN & WHEREWhen: February 9th-12thWhere: Verci, 17 John Street, New York, NY (lower Manhattan)SCHEDULEThursday, Feb 9th - Orientation4pm - Arrival & Registration at Verci, 17 John St5pm - Orientation (10mins) + Intros (80mins)6:30pm - Team FormationEvening/night - Drinks & Mixer (location TBD)Friday, Feb 10th - Hack Day 18:45am - Arrival at Verci9am - Breakfast sponsored by Magna10am - Morning Seminar with Alex Poon and Beth DuttonFull day Hack*Note: Self-organized Lunch and DinnerSaturday, Feb 11th - Hack Day 28:45am - Arrival at Verci9am - Breakfast12pm - Seminar with June Osborne and Phil Dunphy Full day Hack*Note: Self-organized Lunch and DinnerSunday, Feb 12th - Demo Day8:45am - Arrival at Verci9am - Breakfastnoon - Presentations (5mins per project)HOW WILL DEMO DAY WORK?GOOD HACK NYC judges include Alex (CharmVerse), Joel (Last of Us), Fleabag (Fleabag), Mike (Stranger Things), Charlie (Poker Face)On February 12, hackers can submit completed projects, design studies, and proofs-of-concept for public consideration. The best projects will be offered further grants, mentoring, investments, and/or partnerships.

children.title: Rubric

content.text: How original and creative is the idea, and how does it leverage the unique properties of Web3 technology?
How complex is the technical implementation of the project, and does it demonstrate a deep understanding of Web3 principles?
How well-designed and user-friendly is the project, and does it provide a seamless and intuitive experience for users?
How much potential does the project have to create real-world impact and solve significant problems in the Web3 space?
Does the project have a clear and viable business model, and is it sustainable in the long term?
The project does not meet the criteria or is incomplete.
The project partially meets the criteria but has significant flaws or gaps.
The project meets the criteria adequately but has room for improvement.
The project meets the criteria well and demonstrates a high level of skill and effort.
The project exceeds the criteria and demonstrates exceptional creativity, technical expertise, and potential for impact.

children.contentText: Judging Criteria:Innovation and Creativity (20%): How original and creative is the idea, and how does it leverage the unique properties of Web3 technology?Technical Complexity (20%): How complex is the technical implementation of the project, and does it demonstrate a deep understanding of Web3 principles?User Experience (20%): How well-designed and user-friendly is the project, and does it provide a seamless and intuitive experience for users?Impact (20%): How much potential does the project have to create real-world impact and solve significant problems in the Web3 space?Business Model (20%): Does the project have a clear and viable business model, and is it sustainable in the long term?Rating Scale:1️⃣  Poor: The project does not meet the criteria or is incomplete.2️⃣  Fair: The project partially meets the criteria but has significant flaws or gaps.3️⃣  Good: The project meets the criteria adequately but has room for improvement.4️⃣  Very Good: The project meets the criteria well and demonstrates a high level of skill and effort.5️⃣  Excellent: The project exceeds the criteria and demonstrates exceptional creativity, technical expertise, and potential for impact.

children.contentText: Welcome to the Submission page. Please submit prior to the deadline of November in order to have your project considered by the Judges.❗ Note: You must LOG IN [<- add invite link here] as a CharmVerse member (not a guest) to be able to makea submission.👀 How to Submit a Project 👀 Log-in to CharmVerse by clicking "LOG IN" on the  page. Go to  the Submissions page by clicking "Submissions" in the sidebar.Click the 🔽  on the "Create" button on the Submissions page.Choose the proposal template for the area of focus of your project.Title your project and complete the form in the body of the page.Save your proposal by clicking [Save draft]. You may continue to edit your proposal.To submit your project, click [Publish].

content.text: We created this template for your community. Below is a summary of the starting settings that come along with the
template. You can easily change the setup or further customize this space for your community by clicking and exploring
VISIBLE in the side nav bar:
Every member that joins your space will receive the Default role. A default member will have:
Until changed by an Admin, a member with the Default role will be able to:
Create a post in any forum category
Here are a few custom roles to get you started but feel free to create more or import from Discord, CollabLand, or Guild.

Moderate and access all Forum categories

pages.contentText: Attention, Admins! We created this template for your community. Below is a summary of the starting settings that come along with the Hackathon template. You can easily change the setup or further customize this space for your community by clicking and exploring ⚙️ Settings in the side bar.⭐ Feature Custom Names and VisibilityAll 4 features are 👀 VISIBLE in the side nav bar: Member Directory renamed as HackersProposals renamed as SubmissionsForumRewards renamed as Prizes📫 NotificationsIn-app notifications are ENABLED for:✅ Rewards (Prizes)✅ Proposals (Submissions)✅ Polls👤 Default Role PermissionsEvery member that joins your space will receive the Default role. A default member will have:👀 VIEW only access to    and subpages except for  ✏️  EDIT access to   and  Until changed by an Admin, a member with the Default role will be able to:Create a proposal (a submission)Create a post in any forum category🎩 Custom RolesHere are a few custom roles to get you started but feel free to create more or import from Discord, CollabLand, or Guild.ModeratorAssign this role to a member to help moderate your space. In addition to default permissions, a user with the Moderator role will be able to:Create new pagesDelete any pageCreate new rewards (prizes)Delete any rewardDelete and archive any proposal (submission)Moderate and access all Forum categoriesJudgeThe Judge role has FULL ACCESS to  and subpages.The Project Review page contains an inline database with Submissions (Proposals) set as the source. This database serves as a collaborative hub for the Judges, providing a private space for making notes and conducting discussions.The Judge role is assigned as the Reviewer in all of the preset submission (proposal) templates. In addition to default permissions, a user with the Judge role will be able to:Create new pagesCreate new rewards (prizes)Delete and archive any proposal (submission)HackerThe Applicant role has the same permissions as the Default role. A user with the Applicant role will be able to:Create a proposal (a submission) in any proposal categoryCreate a post in any forum category📝 Proposal (Submission) TemplatesA member is required to select a template when creating a submission.You will start with 1 template named Hackathon Project.  The template is a free-form document style and the workflow requires a rubric evaluation step to be completed by users with the Judge role.💬 Forum CategoriesYou will start with these 5 forum categories:AnnouncementsGeneralTeam FormationProject IdeasQuestions & Support

pages.title: Hackathon Project

content.text: Please provide a name for your project.
Provide a brief overview of your project.
Explain the problem your project aims to solve or the opportunity it addresses.
List the key technologies, frameworks, and tools used in your project.
How does your project leverage blockchain technology or web3 principles?
Specify the blockchain platform(s) you are using (e.g., Ethereum, Binance Smart Chain, etc.).
Describe the primary use cases for your project.
Identify your project's target audience or user base.
What sets your project apart from similar solutions in the market?
Explain any innovative or unique features.
Provide a link to a working prototype, demo, or video showcasing your project.
If your project has a user interface, share relevant login credentials or access instructions.
If your project uses smart contracts, provide details about the contract addresses and their functionalities.
Describe any challenges or roadblocks you encountered during the development process and how you overcame them.
Share your vision for the future of your project. What additional features or improvements do you plan to implement?
Is your project open source? If yes, provide a link to the repository. - Specify the project's licensing terms.
Briefly outline the relevant experience and skills of your team members. - Highlight any previous web3, blockchain, or hackathon experience.
List any awards, recognition, or previous hackathons where your team or project has been featured.
Is there anything else you'd like to share about your project or the submission process?
Thank you for participating in our hackathon! We look forward to reviewing your submission and wish you the best of luck in the competition.

pages.contentText: 1. Project Name:Please provide a name for your project.2. Team Information:Team Name (if applicable):Team Members (Names and Contact Information):Roles and Responsibilities:3. Project Description:Provide a brief overview of your project.Explain the problem your project aims to solve or the opportunity it addresses.4. Technology Stack:List the key technologies, frameworks, and tools used in your project.5. Decentralization and Blockchain Integration:How does your project leverage blockchain technology or web3 principles?Specify the blockchain platform(s) you are using (e.g., Ethereum, Binance Smart Chain, etc.).6. Use Cases and Target Audience:Describe the primary use cases for your project.Identify your project's target audience or user base.7. Unique Selling Proposition (USP):What sets your project apart from similar solutions in the market?Explain any innovative or unique features.8. Project Demo:Provide a link to a working prototype, demo, or video showcasing your project.If your project has a user interface, share relevant login credentials or access instructions.9. Smart Contracts (if applicable):If your project uses smart contracts, provide details about the contract addresses and their functionalities.10. Challenges Faced: Describe any challenges or roadblocks you encountered during the development process and how you overcame them.11. Future Development:Share your vision for the future of your project. What additional features or improvements do you plan to implement?12. Open Source and Licensing:Is your project open source? If yes, provide a link to the repository. - Specify the project's licensing terms.13. Team's Experience:Briefly outline the relevant experience and skills of your team members. - Highlight any previous web3, blockchain, or hackathon experience.14. Awards and Recognition (if any):List any awards, recognition, or previous hackathons where your team or project has been featured.15. Additional Comments:Is there anything else you'd like to share about your project or the submission process?Thank you for participating in our hackathon! We look forward to reviewing your submission and wish you the best of luck in the competition.

rubricCriteria.title: Innovation & Creativity
rubricCriteria.description: How original and creative is the idea, and how does it leverage the unique properties of Web3 technology?

rubricCriteria.title: Technical Complexity
rubricCriteria.description: How complex is the technical implementation of the project, and does it demonstrate a deep understanding of Web3 principles?

rubricCriteria.title: User Experience
rubricCriteria.description: How well-designed and user-friendly is the project, and does it provide a seamless and intuitive experience for users?

rubricCriteria.title: Impact
rubricCriteria.description: How much potential does the project have to create real-world impact and solve significant problems in the Web3 space?

rubricCriteria.title: Business Model
rubricCriteria.description: Does the project have a clear and viable business model, and is it sustainable in the long term?

posts.title: Get the conversation started!

content.text: It is easy to start a conversation here, in CharmVerse! Simply click
from the dropdown menu. Make sure to title your post because you won't be able to publish it without one.
When creating a post, you have access to most of the CharmEditor's cool features.
text to style, format, or add a link
to bring up a menu of available blocks. Insert an image or video, embed a tweet or NFT, and more.
-mention a member, role, or even a page to add a useful link
It is also easy to join a conversation! Reply or add your thoughts below a post. The
comments will be threaded and easy to follow. And if you think a post is really amazing, don't forget to upvote

posts.contentText: 👋 Welcome to your CharmVerse Forum!It is easy to start a conversation here, in CharmVerse! Simply click [Create Post] and choose a Category from the dropdown menu. Make sure to title your post because you won't be able to publish it without one.When creating a post, you have access to most of the CharmEditor's cool features.Highlight text to style, format, or add a linkType / to bring up a menu of available blocks. Insert an image or video, embed a tweet or NFT, and more.@-mention a member, role, or even a page to add a useful linkIt is also easy to join a conversation! Reply or add your thoughts below a post. The 💬 comments will be threaded and easy to follow. And if you think a post is really amazing, don't forget to upvote ⬆️ .
